questions.text: Corneal endothelium receives most of its oxygen supply from:

  • • Option D. The vitreous humour is the gel-like substance filling the space between the lens and the retina . It does not play a significant role in supplying oxygen to the corneal endothelium.

  • • retina

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who regularly wears contact lenses came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of severe pain in right eye along with redness and blurring of vision since the past few days. Her eye is shown below. Which of the following given options can be considered for her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chlorhexidine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cefazolin is a cephalosporin antibiotic used against a range of bacterial infections. However, it is not effective against Acanthamoeba and is not used in the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • • Option A.
  • • cephalosporin antibiotic
  • • Option C. Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic . While it is effective against various bacterial infections and is commonly used in treating bacterial keratitis , it is not effective against Acanthamoeba.
  • • Option C.
  • • aminoglycoside antibiotic
  • • treating bacterial keratitis
  • • Option D. Voriconazole is an antifungal medication . While it has a broad spectrum of activity , its use in Acanthamoeba keratitis is more limited. It may be considered in certain cases, particularly for fungal co-infections , but it's not a first-line treatment for Acanthamoeba.
  • • Option D.
  • • antifungal medication
  • • broad spectrum
  • • activity
  • • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • • fungal co-infections

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis, chlorhexidine is considered effective and is commonly used, as opposed to antibiotics like cefazolin and tobramycin or antifungals like voriconazole, which are not primarily effective against this protozoan infection.
  • ➤ considered effective
  • ➤ opposed
  • ➤ antibiotics
  • ➤ cefazolin
  • ➤ tobramycin
  • ➤ antifungals
  • ➤ Ref : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 232
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 232

questions.text: Identify the false statement among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Corneal epithelium being hydrophilic is crossed readily by polar drugs.

options.label: B
options.text: Fluorescein cannot penetrate intact epithelium which forms the basis of dye test.

options.label: C
options.text: Dipivefrin is a pro drug which is converted into epinephrine after absorption into the eye.

options.label: D
options.text: Contact lenses reduce the availability of oxygen to epithelium.

questions.correct_answer: A. Corneal epithelium being hydrophilic is crossed readily by polar drugs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corneal epithelium being hydrophilic is crossed readily by polar drugs.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Fluorescein and Intact Epithelium : Fluorescein cannot penetrate an intact corneal epithelium. The dye test with fluorescein is used to detect epithelial defects ; the dye will only penetrate where there are disruptions in the epithelium .
  • • Option B.
  • • Fluorescein and Intact Epithelium
  • • dye test
  • • fluorescein
  • • detect epithelial defects
  • • only penetrate
  • • disruptions
  • • epithelium
  • • Option C. Dipivefrin as a Prodrug : Dipivefrin is a prodrug of epinephrine . It is designed to be more lipophilic , allowing better penetration through the cornea . Once inside the eye, it is converted to epinephrine .
  • • Option C.
  • • Dipivefrin as a Prodrug
  • • prodrug
  • • epinephrine
  • • more lipophilic
  • • better penetration
  • • cornea
  • • converted
  • • epinephrine
  • • Option D. Contact Lenses and Oxygen Availability : Contact lenses, especially those that are not gas-permeable, can reduce the amount of oxygen that reaches the corneal epithelium . This can lead to complications such as corneal hypoxia , especially with prolonged wear .
  • • Option D.
  • • Contact Lenses and Oxygen Availability
  • • reduce
  • • amount of oxygen
  • • corneal epithelium
  • • corneal hypoxia
  • • prolonged wear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corneal epithelium's lipophilic nature means that it is not readily crossed by polar drugs. Understanding the epithelium's characteristics is important for effective ocular drug delivery .
  • ➤ effective ocular drug delivery
  • ➤ Ref : pg 46/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 46/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd edition

questions.text: The effects of contact lens on cornea include all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced availability of oxygen to the epithelium

options.label: B
options.text: Shift of aerobic metabolism to anaerobic

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of aerobic enzymes such as hexokinase

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lactate levels decrease.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Reduced Availability of Oxygen to the Epithelium: Contact lenses , especially those that are not gas-permeable, can reduce the oxygen supply to the corneal epithelium , leading to hypoxic conditions .
  • • Option A.
  • • Contact lenses
  • • reduce
  • • oxygen supply
  • • corneal epithelium
  • • leading
  • • hypoxic conditions
  • • Option B. Shift of Aerobic Metabolism to Anaerobic: When the oxygen supply to the cornea is reduced due to contact lens wear , the corneal cells may shift from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism to meet their energy needs .
  • • Option B.
  • • oxygen supply
  • • cornea
  • • reduced
  • • contact lens wear
  • • aerobic
  • • anaerobic metabolism
  • • energy needs
  • • Option D. Inhibition of Aerobic Enzymes Such as Hexokinase: Prolonged hypoxic conditions caused by contact lens wear can lead to inhibition of enzymes involved in aerobic metabolism . Hexokinase is an enzyme involved early in the glycolysis pathway , and its activity can be affected by changes in the cellular environment due to contact lens use .
  • • Option D.
  • • contact lens
  • • inhibition of enzymes
  • • aerobic metabolism
  • • Hexokinase
  • • glycolysis pathway
  • • affected
  • • cellular environment
  • • contact lens
  • • use

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Contact lens wear can lead to reduced oxygen availability to the cornea, a shift from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism , and an increase in lactate levels , not a decrease.
  • ➤ reduced oxygen availability
  • ➤ aerobic
  • ➤ anaerobic metabolism
  • ➤ increase
  • ➤ lactate levels

questions.text: Protein synthesis is maximum in which layer of cornea?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epithelium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Stroma: While the stroma is the thickest layer of the cornea and contains collagen and keratocytes , its rate of protein synthesis is less compared to the epithelium. The stromal cells are relatively quiescent under normal conditions.
  • • Option B.
  • • thickest layer
  • • cornea
  • • collagen
  • • keratocytes
  • • relatively quiescent
  • • Option C. Descemet’s Membrane: Descemet's membrane is a specialized basement membrane produced by the endothelial cells . While it does involve protein synthesis , particularly during its formation and repair , it is not the site of maximum protein synthesis in the cornea.
  • • Option C.
  • • specialized basement membrane
  • • endothelial cells
  • • involve protein synthesis
  • • formation
  • • repair
  • • Option D. Endothelium: The endothelium is a single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea . These cells are metabolically active and involved in maintaining corneal hydration and transparency , but their rate of protein synthesis is not as high as that of the epithelial cells.
  • • Option D.
  • • single layer of cells
  • • inner surface
  • • cornea
  • • metabolically active
  • • maintaining corneal hydration
  • • transparency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The corneal epithelium is the site of maximum protein synthesis in the cornea , reflecting its role in continual cell renewal and maintenance of corneal integrity .
  • ➤ site
  • ➤ maximum protein synthesis
  • ➤ cornea
  • ➤ continual cell renewal
  • ➤ maintenance
  • ➤ corneal integrity
  • ➤ Ref : pg 37/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: Metabolic pathways in cornea include all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gluconeogenesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Glycolysis is a fundamental metabolic pathway that occurs in the cornea . It involves the breakdown of glucose to produce energy , and it is especially crucial in the corneal epithelium .
  • • Option A.
  • • fundamental metabolic pathway
  • • cornea
  • • breakdown
  • • glucose
  • • produce energy
  • • crucial
  • • corneal epithelium
  • • Option C. Krebs Cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle , this is a key metabolic pathway that takes place in the mitochondria . The cornea, particularly the endothelium and epithelium, uses the Krebs cycle for energy production.
  • • Option C.
  • • citric acid cycle
  • • key metabolic pathway
  • • mitochondria
  • • endothelium
  • • Option D . Hexose Monophosphate Pathway, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway , is present in the cornea . It's important for generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate , essential for biosynthetic reactions and maintaining redox balance in cells .
  • • Option D
  • • pentose phosphate pathway
  • • cornea
  • • generating NADPH
  • • ribose-5-phosphate
  • • biosynthetic reactions
  • • redox balance
  • • cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the cornea, metabolic pathways like glycolysis , the Krebs cycle , and the hexose monophosphate pathway are active , but gluconeogenesis is not a significant metabolic process in the cornea.

questions.text: Which of the following factors does not contribute to the control of drug penetration through the corneal epithelium?

options.label: A
options.text: Duration of contact of drug with epithelium

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Water solubility

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Duration of Contact of Drug with Epithelium: The longer a drug remains in contact with the corneal epithelium, the greater the opportunity for absorption. Factors such as formulation and viscosity of the drug can affect this contact time.
  • • Option A.
  • • formulation
  • • viscosity
  • • can affect
  • • Option C. Molecular Weight <500: The molecular weight of a drug can influence its ability to penetrate biological membranes .
  • • Option C.
  • • influence
  • • ability
  • • penetrate biological membranes
  • • Option D. Degree of Dissociation of Electrolytes: The corneal epithelium is more permeable to non-ionized ( non-dissociated ) drug forms . The degree of ionization (dissociation) affects drug penetration , as ionized molecules typically penetrate less effectively.
  • • Option D.
  • • more permeable
  • • non-ionized
  • • non-dissociated
  • • drug forms
  • • drug penetration
  • • ionized molecules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The corneal epithelium is lipophilic ; therefore, drugs that are too hydrophilic ( water-soluble ) may have difficulty penetrating it . Optimal penetration often requires a balance between lipophilic and hydrophilic properties .

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of a pain, redness, increased sensitivity to light and blurring of vision in left eye. He gave history of ocular trauma with a twig, 1 day back. After examination, the ophthalmologist suspects fungal keratitis and takes corneal scrapings to confirm her diagnosis. The following organism is observed under the microscope for which immediate treatment is to be initiated to prevent further corneal damage. What is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Natamycin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Amphotericin B is more commonly used for yeast-like fungal infections (e.g., Candida) rather than filamentous fungal infections. It can be used in certain cases of severe or resistant fungal keratitis , but it is not the first choice.
  • • Option B.
  • • yeast-like fungal infections
  • • severe
  • • resistant fungal keratitis
  • • Option C. Fluconazole is effective against yeasts but has limited activity against filamentous fungi. It is not typically the first-line treatment for filamentous fungal corneal ulcers.
  • • Option C.
  • • effective against yeasts
  • • Option D. Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be effective against a wide range of fungi, including filamentous fungi. It is sometimes used in cases where natamycin is ineffective or the fungus is known to be resistant to natamycin . However, natamycin remains the first-line treatment.
  • • Option D.
  • • broad-spectrum antifungal
  • • natamycin
  • • ineffective
  • • natamycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the management of filamentous fungal corneal ulcers, natamycin is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness against common filamentous fungi that cause these infections .
  • ➤ effectiveness against common filamentous fungi
  • ➤ infections

questions.text: A 29-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of a pain in the eye and blurring of vision. She was diagnosed with a corneal ulcer and was sent for corneal scraping. Which of the following topical anaesthetic agents is preferred for the planned procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Proparacaine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lignocaine is a commonly used local anesthetic in various medical procedures, including ophthalmology. However, it is not the first choice for corneal scraping due to its stinging sensation and relatively longer duration of action , which might not be ideal in this scenario.
  • • Option A.
  • • local anesthetic
  • • not the first choice
  • • stinging sensation
  • • relatively longer duration of action
  • • Option B. Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic . Its longer duration and stronger anesthetic effect make it less ideal for short procedures like corneal scraping, where a quick onset and short duration of action are preferred.
  • • Option B.
  • • long-acting local anesthetic
  • • longer duration
  • • stronger anesthetic effect
  • • less ideal for short procedures
  • • Option D. Prilocaine is another local anesthetic , but it is not commonly used in ophthalmology for procedures like corneal scraping. It's more often used in dentistry and for nerve block anesthesia .
  • • Option D.
  • • local anesthetic
  • • used in dentistry
  • • nerve block anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For the procedure of corneal scraping in the treatment of corneal ulcers, proparacaine is the preferred topical anesthetic agent due to its rapid onset of action and short duration , which are suitable for this brief and delicate procedure .

  • ➤ short duration

  • • increasing uveoscleral outflow
  • • reducing intraocular pressure

questions.text: What is the concentration of pilocarpine used in diagnosis of Adie’s tonic pupil?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 0.125%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 0.5% Pilocarpine is a higher concentration of pilocarpine. In a normal eye, 0.5% pilocarpine will cause some constriction of the pupil due to its cholinergic effect on the sphincter pupillae muscle . However, this concentration is too high for the specific testing of Adie's tonic pupil , as it can induce constriction in both normal and affected pupils.
  • • Option A.
  • • higher concentration
  • • some constriction
  • • cholinergic effect
  • • sphincter pupillae muscle
  • • too high
  • • specific testing
  • • Adie's tonic pupil
  • • induce constriction
  • • Option B. 0.25% Pilocarpine: Similar to 0.5%, this concentration is also relatively high for the purpose of diagnosing Adie's tonic pupil. While it might not be as potent as 0.5%, it can still cause constriction in normal pupils, thus not as effective for differentiating Adie's tonic pupil.
  • • Option B.
  • • also relatively high
  • • Option D. 1% Pilocarpine: This is a higher concentration and would typically be used in other clinical situations, not for Adie’s tonic pupil. At this concentration, pilocarpine will induce constriction in almost any pupil, regardless of its normality or pathology , due to its strong cholinergic action .
  • • Option D.
  • • higher concentration
  • • induce constriction
  • • normality
  • • pathology
  • • strong cholinergic action

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When diagnosing Adie's tonic pupil, 0.125% pilocarpine is used, as affected pupils will constrict to this low concentration due to denervation hypersensitivity, unlike normal pupils which show no response.

questions.text: Which layer of the cornea does not regenerate once it is destroyed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bowmans

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Epithelium: The corneal epithelium can regenerate . If damaged, the surrounding epithelial cells will migrate , proliferate , and remodel to repair the defect .
  • • Option A.
  • • can regenerate
  • • migrate
  • • proliferate
  • • remodel
  • • repair
  • • defect
  • • Option C. Descemet's Membrane: Descemet's membrane can regenerate to some extent , especially in younger individuals . Endothelial cells adjacent to an area of damage can enlarge and migrate to cover small defects .
  • • Option C.
  • • regenerate
  • • some extent
  • • younger individuals
  • • area
  • • damage
  • • enlarge
  • • migrate
  • • cover small defects
  • • Option D . Endothelium: The corneal endothelium has limited regenerative capacity . While endothelial cells can enlarge and migrate to cover small gaps , they do not proliferate. Significant damage to the endothelium can lead to corneal edema and vision impairment , as these cells are crucial for maintaining corneal deturgescence and transparency .
  • • Option D
  • • limited regenerative capacity
  • • enlarge
  • • migrate
  • • cover small gaps
  • • corneal edema
  • • vision impairment
  • • crucial
  • • maintaining corneal deturgescence
  • • transparency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the context of corneal anatomy, it's important to recognize that Bowman's layer does not regenerate once destroyed , distinguishing it from other corneal layers like the epithelium, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium, which have some capacity for repair or regeneration .

  • • Option A. Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil and is primarily used to treat conditions like glaucoma. It is not typically used for differentiating episcleritis from scleritis.

  • • Option C. Atropine is a mydriatic agent like phenylephrine but it doesnot have vasoconstrictor properties.
  • • Option C.

  • • Option D. Proparacaine is a topical anesthetic . It is not used for differentiating between episcleritis and scleritis.
  • • Option D.
  • • topical anesthetic

questions.text: Which of the following scleral layer blends with uveal tract?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lamina Fusca

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The supraciliary lamina is a thin, fibrous layer that lies between the sclera and the ciliary body . It blends with the uveal tract , specifically the ciliary body .
  • • Option A.
  • • thin, fibrous layer
  • • between
  • • sclera
  • • ciliary body
  • • uveal tract
  • • ciliary body
  • • Option C. The basal lamina is a layer of extracellular matrix found throughout the body, including in the eye.
  • • Option C.
  • • extracellular matrix
  • • throughout
  • • Option D. Lamina cribrosa is a part of sclera which is sieve-like through which optic nerve fibres pass . Also, it is located at the back of the eye , near the optic nerve head. It is not directly associated with blending into the uveal tract .
  • • Option D.
  • • Lamina cribrosa
  • • sieve-like
  • • optic nerve fibres pass
  • • back of the eye
  • • directly associated
  • • blending
  • • uveal tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The scleral layer that blends with the uveal tract is Lamina fusca .

questions.text: The systemic associations of the given condition include all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Goldenhar Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS), is a group of disorders affecting connective tissues and can present with various signs including hypermobile joints , stretchy skin , and fragile tissues . Blue sclera can be a feature of certain types of EDS , due to the collagen defect affecting the sclera .

  • • Option B. Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI), is characterized by brittle bones that break easily , a feature due to a defect in collagen . Blue sclera is a well-known clinical feature of OI, again due to the collagen abnormality affecting the sclera.
  • • Option B.

  • • Option D. Marfan Syndrome is another connective tissue disorder , with features that include long limbs , fingers , and toes , and cardiovascular anomalies . While Marfan syndrome affects connective tissue .

  • • affects

  • ➤ Goldenhar syndrome, unlike Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Marfan syndrome, is not typically associated with blue sclera.

questions.text: Which of the following passes through the middle aperture of sclera?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vortex Veins

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Long Ciliary Nerve: These nerves are branches of the nasociliary nerve , a part of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve . They typically pass through the sclera around the optic nerve , not through the middle aperture.

  • • Option D. Posterior Ciliary Artery: The posterior ciliary arteries, branches of the ophthalmic artery , supply the choroid , ciliary body, iris, and optic nerve head . These arteries penetrate the sclera around the optic nerve , through the posterior part , not the middle aperture.
